values:
I logged into this journal with the intention of deleting it, but ended up feeling the need to write in it again.  Or at least feeling like I should leave the option open.  
I spent some time reading old entries; it feels weird, like I'm reading someone else's words.  It also makes me aware of the little ways in which I've changed (mostly in terms of perspective).  I haven't really been keeping a paper journal--a few pages here and there, nothing consistent--and while I usually write entries with more substance on paper, this has its place.  
Getting back into the habit of writing is kind of tough...getting past the "back to square one" and "where do I begin?" feeling.
Nothing to write anymore.  I'm fine, looking forward to the coming months, etc.  I'm going to give this thing a break and write later, when I have something to write about.

I have central air conditioning.  It's broken.  This heat makes me want to fling myself off my balcony.  Lucky for me, I have the nicest landlady ever.  She came over and brought me a fan to tide me over for the night until the dudes come to fix the AC.  A fan from her own home.  Which barely does anything, but it's a nice gesture.  

The exhaust pipe decided that it no longer wanted to be a part of my car.  It disconnected at 4am while I was on 95N.  I refused to pull over in the middle of the night (thinking it was my muffler and fully willing to just abandon the damn thing) and drove it (sparking) all the way home.  Today I got it towed.   

I am going to go find an air conditioned place to read now.  For as many hours as they'll let me stay in there.

raiiiin.  Hate it.
I haven't left the house yet today.  I was lucky enough to have that option, and there ain't no way I'm going out there.  Well, at least not until later tonight when I think we're going to cook out in the rain.  
Toxic Holocaust were good last night but sounded kinda wimpy.  Their music didn't have any ASS to it. And they were kinda quiet.  More amps, please.

I started a collage last night, which made me feel good.  I haven't made one in a while.  It feels good to make things.

I share a porch with my neighbor, and yesterday she and I sat out and talked for a long time.  It's nice, to have a neighbor I can do that with.  A few weeks ago I let her use my phone once when hers didn't work, and she bought me a sixpack to say thanks.  Nice lady.  Very baltimore of her.

the identity of deep throat has been revealed.
I guess he was the prime suspect, but...still.  That's kind of a big deal.
My dad helped Woodward with a whole lot of books.  I think he knew about deep throat all along.

Someone broke into my apartment buidling last night.  Stole some stuff from the apartment on the first floor.  I heard the sound of glass breaking but when I looked out the window I didn't see anyone.  I thought it was a car or something.  A few minutes later I heard someone running.  Still couldn't see anything.  The window that they smashed in is directly below mine, so the angle was just right that I couldn't see down there.  A little later I was on my balcony/porch (damn straight I have a balcony) smoking a cigarette and I looked down at the street to see 7 or 8 cop cars and broken glass everywhere.  I called down to one of the cops and asked if something had happened.  He told me there was a break in, I told him what I'd heard.  The cops freaked me out more by asking things like "Are your doors locked?" and "Is there any place a burglar could hide in your apartment building?"  (There isn't...there are only 8 apartments in the building, and a very small little hallway...but still.)
They said "Don't worry ma'am, we've cleared the premises."  I love when cops get all gallant and try to act like a knight in shining-armour. The fact that I was talking to them from my balcony made me feel like the damsel in distress.  
Then we joked about how stupid the dude was for breaking into my apartment building when the richer neighborhood is not that far away.

On a side note, it was strange to be joking around with police.  But I am not someone who "hates cops." I hate some cops, I hate the way the system operates, I hate the idea of police...but I don't hate individual people that I don't know.  People become cops for a variety of reasons.  To some extent, I understand why someone might take the job.  

Anyway.  That's what happened last night.  Crazy shit.  

As for today, I woke up late.  I'm feeling pretty tired, and a little glum.  But I am now listening to good old rock n'roll, and it makes me feel better.

I think it's funny that I don't really like cats, because I think my personality is very cat-like.  I like to have time by myself.  Sometimes I like to be around people, sometimes I'd rather not.  Sometimes I like to be touched, othertimes I will claw the shit out of your hand.  I like to sleep, and I like being awake at night.  I am too curious for my own good.  I like watching from a distance, and don't always like my presence to be known.  Chances are, I don't trust you.  
But I have some dog qualities too.  Loyalty and whatnot.  And unlike a cat, I am not all that graceful.  (Although I know a few cats who struggle in that department...namely, THE LOAF!)

I want to go to all the colleges in the area and get all the shit the students randomly throw away at the end of the year.  People throw away the craziest stuff.  

I would really like DC and Baltimore and Philadelphia to just fucking merge together, without all that delaware/maryland bullshit in between.  I wouldn't have to just sit around missing everybody all the time.

I love this weather.  It not only makes me more productive, but it also makes me happy.  That's right.  I'm HAPPY.  
I think I've been happy for a little over a year, but that the chemicals in my brain were tricking me into being sad.  Now I can actually experience the happiness, and appreciate it in a more complete way.

I've been spending money like it's nobody's business.  But I'd say I'm spending it wisely.  Mostly spending it on music-related things.

Lately all I can talk about is music music music.  I hate that.  I hate when other people do it, and I hate it more when I do it.  But I can't stop thinking about my new amplifier, and how much I want to play music, and how awesome music is, and oh man I love music, and blah blah blah.  And that's just who I am, that's my passion, and I accept (and like) that part of me...but I really don't want to over-talk it to other people.  Especially because I feel that people fall back on music when trying to relate to other people, and that it's misleading.  It says nothing about a person.  It's just the fluff to avoid real content. 

You know those people who are really good at asking the questions?  Like they seem really interested in what you have to say, because they listen and ask follow-up questions and all the rest?  Well, I'm really bad at asking questions.  I try to give the best responses that I can, trying to avoid the reduntant "oh, I'm fine" response while steering clear of subjects that are too heavy, keeping things light, etc.  But then the subject changes and I do a desperate "well wait but how are YOU doing" and they say "oh, I'm fine." By then I'm already feeling stupid and self-absorbed and person "x" is already moving on to social target #14.  Sigh.  

Back to the music part, though...I'm dying to be able to play music in the city I live in.  Even to just rent a practice space for myself, no band necessary, to rock out whenever I feel like it.  To not have to travel miles and miles in order to do this.  

I wanted to go to bed early but that's just not going to happen.

Oh dear god.  FDs are going to record some songs for a tour demo in like 2 weeks and I couldn't be more nervous.  I've recorded many times before, but never with a guitar.  When I get nervous I can still sing, but it's much harder to be nervous and play guitar because my hands shake a little.  I think the solution lies somewhere between 1 and 3 beers.

Luck is not on my side today.  I spent the morning in a building with an apparent toilet paper crisis, and now I'm at home in a building with loud construction workers.  Who start work at around 8:30 am every morning, working on the apartment directly below mine.  Everything in my apartment rattles and buzzes because of the chainsaws.  Either that or because Godzilla is stomping around outside.  I don't think I'm going to get to take my nap.  So I'm drinking coffee instead, and feeling that uncomfortable hyperactive exhaustion.  I tried to wake myself up by listening to speed metal, but it made me feel edgy and anxious.  Or maybe that's the coffee.  I don't know.

I'm running on fumes right now.  Band #2's practice was cancelled today, which in some ways is good because I don't have to make that commute to DC...but now I have nothing to do tonight.  I have no energy but I also can't sleep before 2am.  Staring at the wall might be more fun if I had something ON the walls to stare at.  I have only 4 things on the walls, and out of all of them I only really like one.  The others are just to fill up the empty space.  I really wish I could make this place more like home.

There are never enough hours in the day. 
I am, however, getting better with saying "fuck it." Just rolls off the tongue, you know?

I don't think I've had a girls night in a long long (long) time.  It rules to have women in my life.
Also, my hair is now dyed and looks awesome.  I know this makes the girls night seem more frivolous, to mention 'hair' right after 'girls,' but we're all dudes here.  Dudes with dyed hair.

By this time next week I will have about 1/4 the stress I am feeling right now.  So I will try to remember this as I navegate through the 'week of hell." 

Social awkwardness is lessening.  The past two nights have been really fun, seeing a lot of friends both old and new.  Actually, the whole week has been nice in terms of talking to wonderful people (like ms. corrie).  

I dried the red roses I got for my birthday, because dried flowers look beautiful, and this has sparked another urge to decorate my apartment.  I would also like some cheap furniture for my porch.  Then my home will be complete.

I had a dream last night that I got a hoodie that said "fuck you" on the back of it.  I don't know what the symbolism is there, but that would be a great sweatshirt to break out on college campuses.  Or family reunions.

So after four (yes, four) birthday dinners, the only thing I can say is:  What the hell am I supposed to do with this giant home-made four-layer cake the size of my head?  I know I am unabashedly fond of chocolate and sugar, but...this is a bit much.  (But also very much appreciated.) 

I had an awesome birthday weekend, and feel very lucky.

I also think that the decrease in the amount of my social interactions makes it hard to be social when I do decide to hang out.  It's like playing a piano recital without practicing or something.  I either say too much or too little, and either way, what comes out of my mouth sounds idiotic when I play it back in my head.  

I totally slacked off and am no where close to being prepared for the upcoming week.  And to that I say "FUCK IT."  (Trying to learn to make "fuck it" more prevelant in my mental processes, instead of "oh-my-god-what-am-i-going-to-do-ahhhh".)

Also, I bought my dream amplifier.  A Sunn Model T.  I had bought one before, but fedex damaged it and then lost it when I filed my damaged package report.  Talk about heartbreak.  My money was refunded and all, but this one cost more.  Still totally worth it.
I'm still waiting for it to arrive, praying to the amplifier gods that it gets here safely.  And then I will make beautiful, crushing, loud and heavy music come out of it, and life will be grand.

I can never sleep.  I think that if I slept more there would be a noticeable difference in my general attitude.  Too bad it takes me HOURS to fall asleep.  Godfuckingdamnit.

I wonder how long it takes before memories stop being painful.  When people (or minor threat) say "someday we'll look back and laugh," it's misleading.  If it's laughing, it's only to cover up the ache that comes with remembering.
Sometimes I think I'm good at dealing with change and loss.  Other times, not so much.

Perhaps I wouldn't be so prone to dwelling in memory if I weren't so terrified of the future and preoccupied with my inability to accept the speed of time.  

Sigh.  Same old bullshit.  Don't you wish I were sleeping so I wouldn't be writing melodramatic livejournal entries?  I do.

Each day forces me to readjust.  Readjust to the city I'm in, to the people I'm with or the people I am no longer with, to the routine here instead of the routine there, and even to my self-image in this place as opposed to that one.  I'm trying to master the art of instant camoflauge, like a lizard.  Trying to learn how to blend quickly and without thinking, how to keep moving with the flow.  To fall into step and act like I'd been marching all along.  Why is it that I feel like I'm running with the bulls?
I'm not too interested in surfaces.  I like to dig deeper, to get to the bottom of it all, to take it all in.  But I feel like I'm divided between so many places that I can't really appreciate any of them.  
I'm herded from one place to another and all I can do is feign comfort and hope for stability.  Or at least a break.

I guess I just can't always wrap my head around everything.  Or at least, not enough to properly adjust at the drop of a hat.  I wish someone would just say..."Here you go, here's a break from your inner dialogue and neuroses!  Enjoy!"
I guess some people already have that, and call it "drugs."

I think it's pretty remarkable that I have made it through the winter relatively unscathed and without the aid of whiskey.  Well, not often anyway.  Not like last winter.  I have been feeling really depressed lately, but it is about to be spring, so I'm not so concerned.
But yeah, the season change does make me very nostalgic as per usual.  
The depression will also get better after this weekend comes and goes. I'm going to germany for four days.  To visit my grandmother.  For four days.  Not only is this a stressful enough idea in itself, but my passport is expired.  So tomorrow I get to run around baltimore searching for a post office that will do the emergency passport service.  The thought of anyone in baltimore doing something efficiently is hard to wrap my head around.  I should have tried to do it in DC, where everyone is always efficient all the time.  Because they are robots.  

I have accepted that I do need certain people, that feelings cannot be controlled like a security system, and that it's alright to let myself go.  
But that security alarm still starts going off like crazy, code orange alert, please report to your fallout shelter immediately.  But only when I start to feel the 'need' turn into a gluttonous giant should I really be too concerned.  Self-reliance is great, and I've become a professional--but maybe it's not totally healthy in excess.

My fortune cookie said "you will always be surrounded by true friends."  It complimented my weekend perfectly.

Throw a bunch of manic depressive people together and you'll find that their highs and lows never meet up.  As soon as I'm feeling good about the band, ready to work through the problems, someone else feels discontent and wants to throw it all away.  I am very attatched to both of the bands I am playing in right now, but I've been in one of them for 4 years now and maybe for that reason the thought of it ending makes me panic.
Well either way, not having band practice has allowed me to have the time to buy groceries.  My life is so messy that I'm happy to have plans fall through, even if I really wanted to do them.

I've been going to the gym.  Well, by "have been going" I really mean "2 days in a row."  But I feel awesome about it, and excited to keep doing it.  The depression has been gnawing away at me, but something about excercise really helps keep my mood a little more positive.

This weekend was crazy.  Left friday night, drove 14 hours to arrive in Chicago at 8am, hung out, played a show that night, slept 3 hours, woke up at 6am to go play in pittsburg, got back to philadelphia around 3am.  I got in my car to drive back to baltimore, but by the time I merged onto 95S it was pouring rain, my car's check engine light was on, I couldn't see anything, and I was exhausted.  So I turned around and stayed in philly.  I mean I wanted to stay there anyway, more than anything, I just needed an extra kick in the pants to have the courage to shirk responsibility.  When responsibility is offered up next to the potential to cuddle, the latter will win.

Do you ever notice that when you turn on the radio, the song always seems to have some hidden message that is trying to tell you something?  I turned on the radio when I got on the highway and this is the song:

"Take it eaaasy, take it eaaasy.  Don't let the sound of your own wheels make you crazy."
So then I'm thinking, 'I don't know, should I go back and stay the night in philly?  Maybe I should...'
The song: "Don't say maaaaybe..."

It made me laugh.  But I find that the radio often plays songs that are oh-so-appropriate whenever I turn it on.  
Anyway.  The weekend was really fun.  Stressful, exhausting, but fun.  But goddammit I hate going away for the weekend only to go back to the shit on monday.  It's wednesday and I'm still pouting about it.

Q: Are you lost? A: Yes. Yes I am. If I wrote down my life, mapped it out on paper, it would look wonderful. But for some reason I'm completely and utterly lost in all of it. I always had a fear of ghosts. Not because I thought they were threatening, but because it seems like the worst kind of existance. Between worlds, drifting unheard and unseen, knowing only a painful kind of restlessness without a way to resolve it. I was afraid of ghosts because I couldn't even imagine how awful it must be for a ghost, caught in limbo, waiting to make the final transition to somewhere. I feel like a ghost. I had dinner with my parents last night. My mother said to me: "You know, I remember when you were not more than 10 years old...we were sitting at the dinner table and I asked you how your day at school was. And you said 'oh, school was fine, but I have trouble sleeping.' And I said 'oh no, dear, why?' And you said 'I keep having nightmares because...I feel like life is passing me by.'" Me: "Yeah...not much has changed." My closest friends make comments sometimes about how no one ever really knows me, about how I have this part of me locked away that no one can touch. Maybe they're right, and maybe they're right when they say that I'm protective of it...that I keep it mine and only mine. But I kind of wish it were more accessible. I wonder if that's where the lonliness exists. Because I feel far away from even the people who I'm closest to, who "know me best." And when the people who know me best don't feel like they know me, and I don't feel like they know me (and maybe I don't know them either, who knows), I just feel kind of hopelessly alone. So far away, so incapable of being close. Like I am magnetically charged the wrong way, and there's some force that repels me from other people. The distance might be very small, but it's still a distance. Everyone has a part of themselves that they keep locked away...but I exist in mine SO much that it presents more of a problem when it comes to being around others. I want to listen to more classical music. I was playing piano today and all I could think was "I wish I were just listening, and not playing, so that I could really appreciate this stuff."

I've been thinking that I need to do more to make myself feel good.  Even on the more shallow levels, like buying some new clothes (for once), and giving a shit about my physical appearance in more ways than just the unhealthy ones.  Exercising more, being healthier.  Smoking less?  Making time to do the things that make me happy.  I think I've been ignoring the superficial needs, but I don't think it's superficial to need them.  
I've been sick so long, feeling like a frumpy old blob, and I think I'm starting to go crazy.  
Or maybe it's because being sick makes me watch television, and those commercials that say "pamper yourself" are really starting to get to me.
Either way, I need to, I think.

I've also been thinking about what nationality means in this country.  What "Americanism" means.  Because there is no single American culture to defend.  America is made up of many different and diverse cultures, all of which immigrated from other countries.  The only uniformity in American culture is that Anglo-Saxonism seeks to overshadow and dominate the rest.  Between those cultures exists a very distinct separation, loosely tied together under a flag.  And why?  Immigrants did not come to this country (and we're all immigrants) to be assimilated into the American "melting-pot."  They came in hopes of new opportunity, with ideals of a better future.  They are instead met with disgust and made to feel like "aliens."  And if they do not quickly assimilate, they are scolded for not properly melting into this vacuous pot.  The ruling class determines the ideal, and the ideal has a tenacious allegiance to Anglo-Saxon America.  And in this America, the goal is homogonization--to abandon everything in order to follow the mob.  Everything is in mass, but all that is offered feels like a cheap immitation.  There is no distinctive American culture.  It is distinct in that it is comprised of a diverse range of cultures.  And yet where homogenization fails, division is called to replace it.  Anyone who does not want to abandon their culture upon arrival must be separated, quickly sectioned off.  Because instead of seeing the beauty of diversity, it sees only the threat to Anglo-Saxon values.  Their answer is in mass media, in mass production, mass values, mass culture.  And Americans wander around, detatched fragments of people, aliens to America and yet aliens now even to their former countries.  

Then I've been thinking about punk rock in America.  And how much it's learned from "Americanization."  Under the guise of an open-minded alternative, punk meets its newcomers with disgust and judgement.  It requires complete abandonment of one's previous lifestyle, and only accepts the limited one it defines.  It scoffs at anyone who resists melting completely into its world.  It does not allow for partial citizenship.  Personal freedom is supposed to be an inherent part of the punk ideal, and yet individuality is wrong when it does not adhere to punk standards.  There is no distinctive "punk culture."  There are many different kinds of punk, and yet they remain fairly separate.  It is so wary of "posers" that it alienates its own members, regardless of their authenticity.  "That's not punk."  "That's not American."  "Get out."
And so the individual is left feeling like an alien in every area of the world...not punk enough to be punk, and too punk to be normal.  Constantly judged and excluded.

I realize that this has all been said before.  But I feel like we're all so used to feeling alienated that we don't know what it would feel like to be included.  And I sometimes just feel so tired of being alienated from everything.  Because, really, being an individual is so not okay.

I just freaked myself out.  I had this vivid recollection of calling someone from the library...but then I realized that I did NOT in fact do that, because I left my phone at home.  But I was so sure that I had called, I could picture it in my head and everything.  
I hope this is not an indication that I am losing my mind completely.

I have been sick for a month straight.  I had the flu, which led to bronchitis and the early stages of pneumonia.  I took antibiotics, was starting to feel better when--BAM! I get a massive cold.  Now I am still not recovered, and I'm just letting myself whine.  No more trying to be tough...I'm officially worn down.

I have all these ideas running around in my head, and no way to really write them down.  As soon as I think of one thing, I jump to another.  Maybe later I will feel a little more collected.

So I got a little tired of spending every single night coughing up my left lung.  So I went to the doctor, who confirmed my suspicions that I have bronchitis and possibly the early stages of pneumonia.  And so I had to agree to antibiotics, even though they scare me.  I was really sickly when I was younger (I guess I'm still prone to get sick a lot) and they used to give me antibiotics all the time.  But despite my fears of a future immunity to them, right now they look better to me than a hot fudge sundae.  And not much can top a hot fudge sundae, so that's saying a lot.

I'm trying to be motivated tonight, to get stuff done and to stay productive.  Maybe it's the weather, maybe it's the illness...but all I want to do is sit around and drink hot chocolate and watch movies.  I'm such a slacker.

Tomorrow I go to new york city.  I want to wake up early on wednesday and buy some vegan shoes before we go to philly.  I might lose 2 whole punk points for that, but my shoes have holes in them and that doesn't really agree with the weather.

All my writing about hot fudge sundaes has left me with an intense sweet-tooth, and nothing in the cupboard to satisfy it.  Damn.

So soon I have to make some life decisions.  Big ones.  Ones that will permanently affect at least the next two years of my life.
All I want to do is sleep to escape from the anxiety this makes me feel.  
You know how they say "Well, no one can make your decisions for you!"  Sometimes...just sometimes...I wish that someone could.  That there was a computer program where you could enter the problem and it would generate an answer that said "The best choice is:...."

I don't feel like I have a home.  And everything in my life feels like it's so separate.  Compartmentalized, sectioned off.  Certain parts aren't allowed to merge with others, they are distinctly separated either by thick borders or big gaps.  The isolation is what defines them.  
It makes me feel so scattered, almost schizophrenic.  Or maybe more like a double agent or something.  Yeah, that's better.  That makes it sound more exotic and less disjointed.  Too bad the latter is more like reality.

FUCK THIS, I'M GOING BACK TO KINDERGARTEN!

I tried to stand up for myself today.  I tried to stop playing the role of the martyr and instead to suggest a change in plans that would significanly lighten my stess and maybe help to improve my health.  I'm waiting for the storm to begin, but I'm ready this time.  If it gets out of control I will probably compromise, because it's kind of like a "you agreed to do this and now you're backing out" a.k.a. "you made your bed now lie in it" situation.  But I am going to be strong, and I'm not going to back down until I know that I was at least heard out.  
I need to work on being a little more self-interested.  To not worry about other people ALL the time, at the expense of myself.  I was sort of writing about this earlier and it clicked in my head.  "why do you always make life hard for yourself just to make other people happy, when they won't appreciate it anyway?"  Gotta work on this.  

I had another good day today, except that my stress levels are so high I had to fight off one of my panic attacks.  I managed to get myself under control though.  In between hacking up my lungs and blowing my nose because I'M STILL SICK and it sucks.

Today the internet brought me a letter that really surprised me--in a good way.  It made my day, possibly my week.  I know my last entry is about not expecting much from people, but the letter taught me that people can sometimes go above and beyond what's expected.  I am also feeling significantly healthier than yesterday.  And although I didn't quit smoking, I still managed to make a pack of cigarettes last FOUR whole days, instead of just one.  So it's an improvement, right?  I think I will officially call today "A Good Day."

This weekend would have been fun (going to north carolina), except that I got the flu.  Which meant high fevers and body aches and a cough that made it painful to breathe.  My travel companions were not as unsupportive as they used to be, but instead remained indifferent.  They picked up my slack, carrying equipment when I was incapable of doing so and didn't even complain about it, but wouldn't want to go out of their way to help me out.  I like how other people who didn't know me went out of their way to bring me tea and ask how I was doing, while my own friends sat idle, completely self-absorbed.  But I expected nothing more, and maybe even expected less, so I guess I feel pretty neutral about the whole thing.  They're not spiteful or mean, and they're certainly not bad people, they're just...preoccupied with themselves.  You know..."you're sick, that sucks" without the "you're sick?  how can I help you feel better?"  It wasn't until someone else (a quasi-stranger) said "hey, is there anything I can get you?  Just let me know!  I guess your bandmates are taking care of you though, right?"  And I said "right," while in reality I was thinking "of course they aren't taking care of me...do your friends do that for you? how odd!"  If anything, I can thank these friends for toughening me up, and for teaching me not to expect anything from anyone.   At least this time they weren't mad at me for being sick, or didn't pull the "you're sick?! It's your fault, you have an unhealthy lifestyle!" with a how-dare-you-bring-down-the-band attitude.
I know that perhaps I should make this entry "private," since I'm doing a little shittalking, but I don't care enough to.  No one reads this thing anyway, and I need to vent. 

Luckily, I came home and was taken care of wonderfully.

I feel like I have all these life-decisions to make right now, and not the faintest idea of which direction to go in.  Baby steps, right?

Tomorrow I think I will start chewing the nicorette gum.  God help me.  I'm going to be a raging BITCH if I go through with this quitting smoking thing.

"The philosopher--you know so much about nothing at all."
I love philosophy.  I love reading it, and thinking about it, and getting all nerdy about it.  But then the other part of me thinks: What the fuck do I care about this shit?  Even if I could answer all the questions, it wouldn't do anything."
Which means that I have a love for the most useless, pointless, and pretentious-asshole-ridden subject ever.  Oh well.  I seem to be a sucker for circular thinking and constant deliberation that will get me no where.

I live across the street from a building that advertises as "apartments for the elderly", and diagonally across from "FutureCare," which is an old folks home.  I have an intense fear of old age.  And from my window I watch a dozen ambulances roll up to FutureCare every day.  As if I weren't already hypersensitive to the thought of life passing me by.  Goddammit.

One of my best friends turned into a cokehead.  He moved back out to Denver and when I saw the rest of the crew yesterday they informed me that he was so fucked that they don't hang out with him anymore (and they were like a family).  Apparently my friend said something brilliant like: "Heroin is really great when you're coming down off of coke!"  I'm acting all tough like "yeah, fuck him and his dumb choices."  But in reality, it breaks my heart.  He is/was one of my closest friends.  I guess in as short a time as 6 months, he's changed into someone I don't know at all.  By your late twenties, aren't you supposed to be passed the point of picking up dumb addictions?  Aren't you supposed to be smarter than you were when you were a teenager?  Fuck him and his dumb choices.

I can't focus on anything at all tonight.  I also got sick, and am in that hazy heavy-head stage.  Everything seems like a bummer right now.

I have a feeling that this month will go by as slow as it will fast. 
 
It will also put the band to the test.  "Will they survive the weekend tours?  As the tensions between them threaten to tear them apart, will they continue their torrid affair?  Will Jess' tendency to breathe push them over the edge?  Will Nick's malfunctioning amplifier pull the proverbial rug from beneath their feet?  What evil plan is Brian hatching, anyway?  And will Marshall ever find out about Brian's illegitimate alien baby?   Find out on next week's episode of "Days of Our Punk Lives."  [Cue music.]

My life is full of awesome weekends, followed by grueling weeks.  The former makes the latter a little more manageable.

Tomorrow I will see some out of town friends, and hopefully maintain a sense of responsibility.

Winter is really sucking the life out of me.  Here I was, enjoying a nice week with relatively mild weather.  So feeling hopeful, I check the weather forcast for this week--and it has the audacity to predict ICE PELLETS.  
I may have to join the bears--who are looking more and more to be the much wiser species--and hibernate til spring.  Fuck this shit.

"Hi, please take this complimentary coffee mug! It's free!"
Oh sure.  I'll take anything that's free.  And what does it say?  "GET BACK TO WORK."  
Sigh.

I wrote a letter to my grandmother today to thank her for the neon green velour jogging suit, the sequined santa claus hat, the party favor (you know, the kind that you blow into and it honks), and the lime green nightshirt she sent me.  I don't jog, I was raised Jewish and became an atheist, I don't have party favors at parties, and I don't sleep in nightshirts.  Oh well.  Better than the hot pink sweatpants she sent last year.  Bad taste is the only typical grandmother quality that she possesses--otherwise she is just mean and cold.  I could tell amazing stories about her and all the fucked up shit she's done, but she seems to be a little better these days.  Last time I saw her, she told my mother that I was pretty.  If you knew her, you would find that as shocking as I did.  I guess she was so skilled in the insults department that she decided to branch out at age 85 and give compliments a shot.  I've only seen her do it once, and she finds it so foreign and uncomfortable that her face still contorts into a strange sneer.  She talks through her teeth, without moving her jaw.  

Words cannot express how excited I am to go to sleep tonight.  I pulled my back this weekend, which led to the side effect of a perpetual headache, followed by a strong dependency on Aleve.  That stuff is the shit, by the way.  

But the good news is that I am now the proud owner of a microwave!  Behold the power of quickly prepared food.

"...Our most bitter disappointments, our brightest hopes and ambitions, are known only to ourselves.  Even our friendship and love we never fully share with another;  there is something of every passion, in every situation, we conceal.  In hours like these we realize the awful solitude of individual life.  There is a solitude which each and every one of us has always carried with him, more inaccessible than the ice-cold mountains, more profound than the midnight sea; the solitude of self.  Our inner being which we call ourself, no eye nor touch of man or angel has ever pierced..for to it only omniscience is permitted to enter."
-E.C. Stanton

<lj-cut>
For some reason, I always clung to the desire to be alone.  At times in my life I was extremely social, maybe too social--but ultimately needed time alone as much as I needed oxygen.  I associated being alone with being strong, and with being real.  And I am good alone.  Being alone and being lonely are two very different things...and although I experience lonliness from time to time, I still love the time I have alone.  The problem is trying to be flexible enough that I can be comfortable alone as well as comfortable with others.  If I spend a day alone, I am productive, creative, and secure.  I know exactly what I want to do, where I want to go, etc.  But as soon as I'm with someone else I become useless, unsure of what to do, what to eat, where to go.  It's not that I lose myself in others, but rather that I don't know how to share myself.  I am trained to be alone, to look out for myself, to be strong.  However I am NOT so sure how to be cared for, how to let other people in, how to balance out their desires with my own.  When to compromise, when not to.    
I spent so much time shutting people out that now I don't know exactly how to let them in.  And I WANT to let them in.  Four different people in the last month said something about "you're a very private person."  Not a compliment, not an insult, just an observation.  And I wanted to scream "no I'm not! I'm open!  Ask me anything, I'll tell you whatever you want to know!"  But they're right, I am.  I might have an online journal, but almost never mention anything concrete about my life.
I don't know how to make decisions for more than myself.  For instance, if my best friend says "jess, what do you want to do today?" I'll say "I don't know, what do you want to do?"  And she'll say "I don't care, you decide."  And I can't.  I am simply incapable of making a decision when it involves more than just me.  Because I know how to make others happy (if she said what she wanted to do, chances are I'd do it without question), and I know how to make myself happy on my own, but something about the combination makes me lose the ability to function.

I feel like if I am alone, I will at least not be fake.  I have no one to impress, I can't acquire an interest to look good to someone else, I can't brag about some new obscure band I like, I can't show off the latest trend.  I might not know the trends, or care about finding obscure bands, or pick up new interests, or impress anyone...but at least I know who I am.  The more unconnected I am socially, the more confident I am that I am indeed ME.  Turns out, I am a gigantic nerd.  I realized this when I made a myspace profile.  I am LAME!  But at least my lameness is honest.  
The thing is, is that it is totally possible to be a social animal and not be "fake."  I am pretty secure in who I am, and don't know why I would think that being social would jeopardize that.  I guess it's just that I'm human, and EVERYBODY does certain things that have something to do with impressing somebody else.  And I guess that instead of accepting that human quality in myself, I decided to reject it at the expense of having a social life...instead of just rejecting it and being confident enough in that rejection (even if it should sometimes be imperfect) to be social.

Wow this is long-winded.
I think that if someone who didn't know me read this journal, they would think that I am a very different person than I am.  Or maybe just that I take myself too seriously.  Hah.  I'm thinking that I write this way here because it is my only outlet for these kinds of thoughts...it's not like the time is right to sit and spew philosophical shit when I'm just hanging out with someone.
But I swear, I can be fun!  Really I can.  

In other news, I wish girls had a different way of interacting.  I get kind of sad when I'm hanging out with people and the women completely ignore me.  There's so much female competition, a sense of one-upping that always plays a part in women's interactions with each other.  And then the constant shit-talking, the wariness, the judging eye.  I'm not saying that I'm never jealous.  I would be telling a big lie if I said that.  But I try to recognize it and monitor it.  I feel like if I just admit "ok, so maybe I feel a little jealous about how pretty and awesome she is," then I can just say "she is pretty and awesome, and that has nothing to do with me, and maybe I should talk to her since she seems cool."  We're just so programmed to see it as threatening, instead of good.  It's so engrained in our heads that it escapes all rational thought.  We don't even know what we're competeing FOR, just that we're competing.  We have no one to impress, but just this strange innate sense that we should be impressing somebody.  I'm much better about that now.  I don't play that game anymore.  And I value the women in my life more than anything, even if they are few.
But hey, we're all dudes here.  

I think I'll stop now, or else I will just go on for hours.

If my arms are full and I'm handed something more to carry, I just make room.  Instead of finding a way to avoid adding more weight to the load, I just accept it and keep walking.  Instead of thinking "hey, maybe I should try to make this load a little lighter," I instead think "hey, I guess I should work out more so that I can handle this kind of weight."  I just accept it all.  I just say "well I guess this is something I will live with, no big deal."   
I can take a lot of punches and still bounce back, but I think I have some major internal bleeding.  
The problem is that I don't ever face any of it, I don't work on anything.  My subconscious screams at me in my sleep, in the form of nightmares.  But I just can't deal with any of it, I stuff it down and shrug and move on.  The issues manifest themselves in different and subtle ways.  They're clever--they don't leave fingerprints, they can't be traced, they don't sign their name to their letters.  

I don't mean to complain, or whine, or pity myself.  I'm just trying to figure out a way to face all of it without completely obliterating the ground I stand on.

[edit: why do I write about things I'm not comfortable having an INNER dialogue about, let alone broadcasting to the internet?  This paragraph was deleted.]

In other news, silk's soy chai is the greatest thing to hit supermarkets since fake meat.

I am reading a book called "understanding islam" because I feel like I have definite gaps in my understanding of Iraq.  Newspapers write about current events as if Iraqi history is common knowledge.  Or they simply choose to ignore history altogether.  
Three chapters and I already feel I have a much better grasp on the whole thing.  

I had a dream last night that it was spring.  What a shitty dream to wake up from.  Winter is starting to wear me down, I think.  I recognize the patterns in my mood-swings.  Goddammit.

I am one of the insatiable ones.  Always pushing for more, never quite happy where I stand.  The kind who clings naively to hope for a future, who even thinks that her dreams can somehow be realized in a world as unforgiving as this one.  I guess I'm setting myself up to lose.  I know that in my own eyes, I'll die a failure.  And maybe that's okay.  Or if not okay, it's at least "typical."

Sometimes it would be nice if life really were like a book--where you can pick and choose the right moments to include, trim the fat of your life, and call it "a complete work."  Where your imagination can fill in the gaps and reconstruct everything according to what seems right.  

Fumbling around in that strange space between dream and reality.  Words and action.  
Sink or swim.
I am one of the hopeless romantics, one of the hungry ones.  And I know that I like the feeling of hunger more than I like to eat.  

And here I am, forever young, screaming "I'll never settle! I'll never be boring!"  And wondering why I'm standing there alone, and why everyone seems to resign themselves to that fate in the end.  And maybe my view really is just a symptom of being young, this notion that being settled means being bored.  But we dreamers, we're always bored.  Wherever we arrive, we keep our shoes on.  We keep moving.  

But no one ever dies feeling fulfilled.  No one is ever "done" with their life by the time it's over.  So I guess we all die failures in the end.  There's no room for our futures in this world.  There's no where to go.

And I just feel like the more time that passes means more chance for regret.  And more people there are to miss.  And more moments there are to replay over and over until they're dull and thin, laced with regret.  Or at least frayed by nostalgia.  And every moment that goes by gives nostalgia more ammunition.  That fucking nostalgia.

I'm happy in the moment, and I wish I could say "that's enough."  But the future is held out like a carrot on a string, and I can't help but try to swat at it every now and then.  Grabbing at the air and thinking "goddammit all I want to eat is a fucking carrot," even when I'm full from a huge meal.  I think I'd rather spit out the food in my mouth just so that I don't miss the opportunity to eat the stupid carrot.  I don't even like carrots that much.  The grass is always greener, isn't it.

And I'm one of the lucky ones, convinced that luck can only last so long, that the best has happened and the worst is sure to come.  So afraid of what's ahead that I can't even see what's around me sometimes.
But it's funny, because what's around me is the best shit ever.

Get past the crust and there's just this soft dough-like substance underneath.  With some semi-firm ingredient in the middle.  
That's me, summarized.  I have determined that I am a sandwich.

I've noticed that being happy means that a lot of my music is off-limits.  Which doesn't mean I like any of it any less, but that it threatens to bring me back to sad places.  And those places are always going to be a little tempting, I think.  Sadness does have a certain beauty, doesn't it?

This week, my goal is to make my apartment feel a little more like "home."  I still feel very ungrounded, and perhaps as a result of that I neglect my own space.

I haven't gotten drunk in over a month.  Maybe that's why I have a fucking HANGOVER today, and I can't believe I am such a lightweight.  I really got nostalgic, and wanted more than anything to listen to skynyrd.  I was even drinking jack daniels, which is a step up from Old Crow (sold in a plastic half-gallon jug).   Unfortunately, my present company wouldn't have enjoyed it.  Is it wrong of me that I respect people less when they don't agree with me in certain matters of taste?  Rhetorical question.  Anyway, we listened to old punk and good metal and still had fun.  The people at the bar got to be pretty annoying, but I was entertained for a little by this drunk moron: 
1.)  (slurring) "I'm the last chaos punk in baltimore!  I'm the last one here...'cept for all those young kids, but...but I'm the last chaos punk of my generation!  How does that make you feel?"
2.)  (still slurring)  "Dude...I don't know why that guy's mad at me.  I even offered to split my beer with him!  He TOLD me to hit him in the face with a doll.  I didn't even hit him that hard, but he TOLD me to.  Never ask a drunk guy to hit you, 'cause...(long pause, slightly dramatic) I mean, you know he'll always do it."

I didn't play the best game of pool ever, but I'm going to go ahead and blame the drunkeness.  You know, like when you suck at nintendo and passionately insist that the buttons were sticking.  In other news, I still don't like the beastie boys.  

I got into a debate about monogamy vs. polyamory last night.  I've done both before, but it's really nice to sit here and think "I reaaaally don't want to be with anyone but him, with or without the option to," and truly mean it.  I try not to talk about this kind of stuff in this journal though, as I'm sure it's nauseating.  Somebody once told me that monogamy was a symptom of the catholic church, and therefore should be opposed.  Um, okay.  Last night I did my best to explain that it's not so much a moral stance on monogamy more than the fact that everyone pales in comparison to what I have.
To each his/her own.  

I need to not spend any money today.

I'm really excited about the new radical bookstore/coffeeshop in baltimore called Red Emmas.  I went there yesterday and it's big, with a huge sign on a main street.  It looks like a regular coffeeshop but then has all this awesome literature inside...and a pretty extensive collection, at that.  It apparently has a steady clientele that includes non-activists (and hasn't been completely overrun by wingnuts yet). They also have awesome coffee.  They say they think they'll be around for a good long while.  Call me crazy, but I'm proud of Baltimore for this.

It's a dreary and gray kind of day, but for some odd reason I'm still in a good mood.  Go figure.  It might just be the surge of energy I got from making my coffee too strong, but I'll take what I can get.

Even cleaning isn't making me feel any more "together" today.  I feel motivated, but unsure of where to direct my energy.
My to-do list is long, and nothing is checked off.  And the weather is so nice today, but I don't know how to really take advantage of it.  I rode my bike for a little bit but but my hands are cracked and dry and I don't have gloves.  

I remember reading a poem not too long ago which started with something like "all life is is a paper bag floating in the wind" and remember thinking "what a lame poem."  But now I keep seeing all these bags floating around on the streets of Baltimore, and those stupid lines play in my head.  Then I indulged in the geekiness of it all, and decided that if I were a bag floating in the wind, I think I would be at the moment where it just sort of hangs in midair for a moment, hovering.

I think it's sad that my life is so on-the-go that reading is on my to-do list.  That should be a given, not something to make time for.  I think there are a lot of things that should be part of everyday living that are cast to the wayside in favor of responsibility.  Modern life is structured in such a hierarchical way, and I can't really decide what should go in front of what, what should take priority.  Then again, I don't know what to do with time when I have it.

I'm not sure how to react to 2005.  I don't have any resolutions, because I always break them.  I'm about to break my quit-smoking resolution, because tomorrow was my "quit date" and quite frankly it isn't gonna happen.  Instead, I'm doing little things to improve life.  I'm trying to wake up earlier in the morning, because I think it helps make me less depressed.  I bought a book on knitting so that I can learn to make more than just scarves (I must have made about 50 scarves by now, but nothing else...), I will sort out my guitar woes so that I can push forward without having money on my mind, and I am going to start reading all the "classic" books that I should have already read instead of the four thousand murder mystery novels I've read in my lifetime.  Next up: Crime and Punishment.  And since it's winter, I am going to start watching all the "classic" movies I should have seen.  I've seen the black and whites...I'm talking about the more recent classics that people quote all the time and I never know what they're talking about.  
My father didn't see The Wizard of Oz until he watched it with me years later...he always talked about how strange it was trying to keep up when people kept saying things like "I don't think we're in kansas anymore" or "there's no place like home" or "I'll get you my pretty" without having seen the movie.  I told him nowadays we just say "WHAT?! YEAH!" Thank god I've seen the Chapelle show--otherwise pop culture quotes would have left me in the dust.  My dad was bummed though, he thought he was pretty up to date ever since he started saying "totally cool."  I feel like I'm alright since I have the Big Lebowski pretty much committed to memory.

I don't usually have good luck with new years eve plans.  This new years was really nice.  Quiet, but really nice. 
So yeah, it's 2005.  The second half of 2004 made up for the first, so I'm hoping to keep that energy going.  Right now, all that is on my mind is: music music music music music music music.  But the space in between is filled in nicely.  I know I have to make some changes in order to be happy, but I think that will happen eventually.  Tonight I looked at a glass filled with water and said it was half-empty...my friend joked that perhaps I need a new outlook.  She's probably right.  I'm working on it.  I wonder if it's an inherent part of my personality to never be satisfied.  High expectations?  I guess I'm grateful for it, if only because it makes me push to get the most out of life.  Rest assured, I hope to milk it for all it's worth.

If I am ever found dead and the police claim that it looks like suicide, please make sure they know to start a murder investigation.  

But I haven't been in those dark mental places for a very long time, and while I do credit myself for about 70% of my improvement (and maybe 10% on being a teenager) I am eternally grateful for all the amazing people who helped me to feel strong over the years.  I'm happy to be in the place I am, and even happier when I look at the people around me.  Sometimes it scares me how much I can love once the walls are down. 

Anyway, the bottom line is that I feel very lucky.  And happy to be alive.  And not sure what 2005 will bring, but ready to take it on.  It really did sneak up on me, though...I had only recently gotten used to being in 2004.

I'm obsessed with being strong and never weak.  The problem is that I seem to perceive things as weaknesses when they are quite possibly strengths.  Also that I seem to be a little too hard on myself.  Everyone's got insecurities and weaknesses...so maybe it's okay that I do too.  I know this isn't really profound, and seems really obvious, but...I think I just needed to write it down.

I was actually really social this weekend.  It felt good.  

But seriously, if I wanted 19 degree weather, I'd be living in Chicago already.  I'm not living there because I wanted to avoid 20 mph winds and below-freezing temperatures.  This is seriously offensive.

gears shifting, locking, grinding.  Envy kissed me on the cheek, and I swallowed her whole.  Coffee made me buzz like a neon light and I think I started to hear things.  Loss whispered in my ear, seductive in a way, "lose everything to gain everything," it said.  But I looked at everything as it is now, and loss seemed eery and terrifying and I started furiously writing my name on everything I owned.  But I can't write my name on the things I don't own, and that's when I started to worry.  When I hear sirens I get so nervous, and I can taste my stomach, and my worst fears start flashing like a slide show on my eyelids.   My nose bled today, only a little.  I blew my nose and there it was all dried and brown.  I wondered if that's what my insides look like, all dried and brown.  I thought about that saying: "we're all pink on the inside" and I wonder if all my self-hatred really comes from the fact that I hate the color pink.  What an unfortunate color.  I stuck my hand out the window and the cold stabbed at my joints and the breeze pushed winter in through my window.  I thought about all the heat that little gust stole from me and cursed at the air as if it were alive.  And for a minute I thought that maybe it was, because it was moving, and it was going somewhere, and that's more than I can say for myself sometimes.  And from my window I saw an elderly woman walk down the street, struggling, and I thought about time passing and got scared.  I really want to be something, you know?  Before I die I want to read a biography about my life.  Because someone would have written one, because surely I would have done something worth writing about.  Right?  Except that I'm moving about as slow as that fucking old woman, and I feel like I'm on pause.

The last week was stressful--a lot of running around, and a lot of it in the rain.  Now I'm just getting ready to churn out another week and then sit back and relax for a minute.  Still getting hit with waves of unnecessary insecurity.  I treat it kind of like I treat nausea...push it down, breathe deep, move on.  And/or ask (outloud or in my mind) everyone I come in contact with: "what are you thinking?  You're not upset with me, are you?"  Jesus I'm an idiot sometimes.
I think that this time in my life is the ending of a cycle, and that I'm about to start a new one.  I'm optimistic.  I have some changes to make, but a solid base from which to make them.
Lots on my mind.  And a lot of things I'd like to write here (semi-publicly, I mean)...but tonight is not the night to start.

- It's official.  I'm not doing what I want to be doing with music.  I am playing in other people's bands.  I'm confused about one and having fun in the other (even if it doesn't feel like mine).  But... to have one that could really feel like MINE--where I'm WRITING music as well as playing it, where I have an equal say in the whole process--that would be nice.   
- I feel completely alienated when I go back to DC.  
- I am feeling a lot of stess, coupled with exhaustion
- I'm uncomfortable with how I'm seen in the eyes of others (or that I don't have a clue HOW I'm seen)...and even more uncomfortable with the fact that I care.
- My car isn't functional
- It's raining outside
- The collage I was making didn't turn out the way I wanted it to.
- I haven't read a novel in months.
- I need a job (as in not the black cat, where I only work once a week anyway)
- I'm not going to atlantic city after all

+ I have amazing people in my life
+ I have aweomse and inspiring conversations with those people
+ I've started to draw again
+ Holiday season means that maybe I'll have some money to buy pants WITHOUT holes in them
+ I don't have to work this weekend
+ It's not supposed to rain tomorrow
+ I'm in the process of figuring shit out, with confidence in my ability to change things.

My stress levels are rising.  One cup of coffee and it's "OH MY GOD WHAT AM I DOING WITH MY LIFE?!"
And of course no one can ever answer that question.
I'm feeling a little stressed.

On a side note...
I noticed that when people show me support, I get weirded out.  "What are their motives for being supportive?  Are they being serious?  What do they really think?  What do they want in return for this display of support?"
That's sad, that to be supported doesn't feel natural.  Always narrowing my eyes and thinking "where's the catch?" 
But although the past might have bruised me a little, it's nice to know that my present has a lot of awesome and supportive people in it.

But on the other side of that coin...
why is it that some people think that it's their god-given duty to discuss whether MY decisions are right or wrong...or better yet, to "inform" me of my "mistakes" without being "informed" of the situation (ahem: MY situation in which they are not at all involved) in the first place?  Am I supposed to appreciate the concern?  Because it really doesn't feel like CONCERN--I don't feel like these people actually care too deeply about me or my decisions--but rather some sort of bizarre self-interest.  Boredom, maybe?  I welcome the people who care about me to make comments about my life...but I don't welcome the uninformed judgmental peripheral people.  This seems rational, doesn't it?  If my decisions don't affect you at all, why do you care?  If your concern does not come from love, then why would I be interested?  Just because you like to hear yourself talk does not mean that I do.

Sometimes I do need to use this thing to bitch and whine.  Please forgive me.

I have been especially emotional these past few days. The little things, the big things...I've been reacting to the world in a very emotional way. I think that it strikes me as odd these days, although a few years ago I would have thought it was normal. Over time I think that the rational part of my brain took control over my not-so-rational heart. I've taken a very calculative approach to my life, and even a logical approach to my feelings and emotions. If I felt something that didn't seem rational, I would convince myself to feel otherwise. And I know that emotions are rarely felt because they're rational. But over time I actually became pretty good at training my heart to coincide with my brain. I'm not sure that this was the best thing to do. Safer, maybe. But it is a very cold way of looking at the world. I guess it was a response to being overly emotional in the past. To "feel" meant the possibility of feeling pain. I used to feel so much that I was constantly overwhelmed. To make thing rational meant that I was guarded by that logic, that I could defend myself against...well, myself. No matter what happened, I could deal with it. When the shit hit the fan, I could numb myself to the initial emotional response and then have the ability to work through it rationally. Where my emotions failed, reason prevailed. I could choose when to feel, and when to be numb. I was protected. The only problem is that the numbness took over. And to be numb is far worse than being sad. Worse than depression, numbness is hollow. The kind of emptiness that is tantamount to feeling dead. At least sadness is a feeling. At least it makes me feel alive. The only place I designated for my emotions was music--and I can't live my life in a song. I think I am willing to take risks now. Willing to be a little emotionally vulnerable, even though I know that I might get hurt. Accepting the potential of downs as a means to fully experience the ups. I want to really experience life, and not just to survive it. I used to write poetry. Now I write essays. It would be nice to do both. p.s. Falling in love? Best thing ever. I've never been so happy to be so vulnerable. Highly recommend, A+, would love to continue doing business with.

When the cold arrives, I start to panic. I have never had a happy winter. In addition to depression, it usually brings out all of my self-destructive habits. I am hoping that love is going to get me through this winter. I need to surround myself with it. Luckily, I have that option. That, and a very bright lamp that is supposed to help with seasonal depression. Fake sunshine. There's something really unsettling about that. I know that music is the driving force behind...well, most of what I do. But right now I'm not sure exactly what I'm doing in regards to playing it. I have the opportunity to play music all the time, but I still don't feel like I have a place to write it. No creative output. I think that words need to be put into action, and soon--a.) because I'm getting really ansy and feel a little unfulfilled and b.) because there's a lot of potential in the projects I've been discussing with other people.

Generally, when I look back at my life, I'm fairly proud to be where I am--and who I am--now.  But I can't shed or control my insecurity, which absolutely disgusts me.  I always feel this subconscious need to prove that I'm beyond it, which I can see in the way I sometimes speak, but in doing so am emphasizing its existance.  It makes me feel very young, almost backwards.  Makes me question the progress I've made over the years.

I am not going to write very much about the election.  I feel like my stomach has been ripped out of my body and ground into the floor.  To the world, I apologize for this country's government, for the people who put it there, and for the massive amount of suffering it will cause.  To Americans, I apologize in advance for the inevitability of our exploitation.  To my future children, I apologize for my failure to give you a better world, and for the ugliness of the one you will live in.  To America's president, I hope you rot in hell.
And so it begins.  The Reign of Terror part II.

My mother is coming to Baltimore and is going to take me out to dinner.  She has never come here to see me before.  I'm actually really excited about it.  I have a lot of faith in our relationship these days.

First things first...slaytallica was awesome.  You couldn't hear my vocals very well, so I'm told, but I did manage to remember all the words to angel of death and rock out a lot, and have a fucking awesome time.  People went so nuts that I left the performance bruised and bleeding...which I think is appropriate.  I also had (and still have) a severe bangover.  
So singing slayer and metallica songs was a dream in and of itself...but more than that, it was really fun to get out of my own personality for a minute while I was on stage.  It is much harder when I'm representing myself (in my own band)...my actual personality is the opposite of a "lead singer."  It is easier to assume someone else's personae.  I got to really rock out and enjoy it.  
I did watch Cliff 'Em All and some slayer videos to get the stage banter down.  We all thought the banter was important.  I wish we had played "die by the sword" so that I could have used the stage banter I saw on the video:

"They say that the pen is mightier than the sword...but I say FUCK the pen, because you can die by the sword."

The dude danny, who practiced with us maybe 3 times (he got back from germany on monday)...played every solo flawlessly.  One of the most amazing guitar players I've ever seen in my life.

We had so much fun that we might even play again.

Unfortunately, I got food poisoning later that night.  And am waiting to recover.  I have been sleeping an extraordinary amount, and feel a little disoriented.

Having a guitar makes my solitude a little less lonely.  It is the most beautiful thing I've ever seen or heard.  I suppose most people would wait until they're super good to buy a guitar like mine, but I think I've played long enough to know that it's not something I'm ever going to stop doing.  And it's the one things that consistently makes me happy, without fail.  Having my own guitar makes playing it even more amazing.  
Oh dear god, I'm never going to leave the house.  
Unless it is to play out of someone else's amplifiers, because that is something I don't have (and can't afford) for a while, and makes the whole experience euphoric.  

So the band that stayed at my apartment on saturday might stay here again tomorrow since one of their shows fell through.  I hope it is a little more tame than it was before, because last time was pretty crazy.  It turned into a full on party.  The neighbors might have put up with me before, but I don't want to push it by doing it again on a weekday.  We shall see.

I know that lately my lifestyle has left me feeling a little lonely, but hanging out with aquaintances only leaves me feeling unfulfilled.  I think that as a whole, I enjoy my small world more than I enjoyed my bigger one.  I might be a little too picky about who I spend time with, but at least I always know that it will be time well spent.  There are, of course, many people who still have a permanent spot in my heart regardless of time or amount of interaction...and with those people I do wish that those interactions were more frequent.  

I'm playing in a cover band for halloween.  Details to follow.

Well, it's already happened.  Winter hasn't even arrived and I got sick.  So I didn't buy the guitar today.  Tomorrow, however, is another day.  It has to be tomorrow because I'm losing sleep about it I'm so excited.

I hate being sick, especially since I live alone, but I must say I don't mind piling on the blankets and drinking tea and watching movies for a little while.
